abstract.text: A container for the node hierarchy and global properties that together form a displayable 3D scene.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: To display 3D content with SceneKit, you create a scene containing a hierarchy of the nodes and attributes that together represent your visual elements. Typically, you build your assets in a 3D visual editor, then assemble them into a scene using Xcode’s SceneKit Scene Editor, ready for SceneKit to render.
To display your scene, you need to load it at runtime, then set it as the scene property of an

code: else { fatalError("Unable to load scene file.") }

inlineContent.text: The simplest way to create a scene is through Xcode’s SceneKit Scene Editor. Start by importing one or more assets from a 3D editor, such as Blender. Then you adjust the positions and attributes of the assets, and set global scene properties, such as lighting environment, to compose your scene. The scene editor creates a
file, which you save to a
folder in the app bundle. When you build your project, Xcode optimizes the scene file for your target platform.

abstract.text: Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
A container for the node hierarchy and global properties that together form a displayable 3D scene.
Attaches a particle system to the scene, using the specified transform.
Returns the scene attribute for the specified key.
A background to be rendered before the rest of the scene.
The color of the fog effect to be rendered with the scene. Animatable.
The transition curve for the fog’s intensity between its start and end distances. Animatable.
The distance from a point of view at which the scene’s contents are completely obscured by fog. Animatable.
The distance from a point of view at which the scene’s contents begin to be obscured by fog. Animatable.
Loads a scene from a file with the specified name in the app’s main bundle.
Loads a scene from a file with the specified name in a specific subdirectory of the app’s main bundle.
Loads a scene from the specified URL.
A Boolean value that determines whether to run actions, animations, particle systems, and physics simulations in the scene graph.
A cube map texture that depicts the environment surrounding the scene’s contents, used for advanced lighting effects.
The particle systems attached to the scene.
The physics simulation associated with the scene.
Removes any particle systems directly attached to the scene.
Removes a particle system attached to the scene.
The root node of the scene graph.
Creates and returns an empty scene.
Creates a scene from the specified Model I/O asset.
Sets a scene attribute for the specified key.
Exports the scene and its contents to a file at the specified URL.
Methods you can implement to participate in the process of exporting a scene to a file.
The signature for the block that SceneKit calls during scene export.
A view for displaying 3D SceneKit content.
Attribute keys available in the options dictionary for the methods
and
Options for the
method.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
Identifies scene classes from other frameworks that support embedded GameplayKit information.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.

media-2994226.alt: At the left, a diagram showing a simple scene composed of the node hierarchy and presentation attributes. At the right, the resulting rendered scene.
